comments.commentBody:
Peter, your suspicions are well founded. However, Dropbox and similar sites do not simply provide file storage. They provide backup, the ability to access one's data from multiple computers, and, most significantly, the ability to share large files with other individuals.

So, if you simply create your own documents on one computer, fine. But most people use multiple computers and live in a social world of shared information. No man is an island!

Peter.. I'm assuming that you unplug and take your hard drive with you every time you leave home/work? If you ever had a burglary or fire (or even flood, earthquake, tornado) you may well lose your computer AND your backup. I've worked in this industry for over 32 years, and always advise people to keep an off-site backup for just that reason. For people who don't want to use cloud back-up, I recommend that they do a full system back occasionally and leave the back-up in an alternate geographical location.
I hope that your external hard drive never crashes at the same as your computer - as recently happened with one of my clients. Cost them $2500 and clean-room technology to recover their data.

You have no way of knowing whether your hospital, doctor etc. is archiving locally or using a cloud based service. What do you think banks do? Or the government?

Do you use a credit/debit card? A store based customer card? Do you always surf the internet using an anonymous browser? Do you delete your internet cache & cookie file every day?

Your information is out there... in the cloud, whether you like or not.

Steve Jobs didn't invent the idea of cloud based computing - it's been around for many years - the public is just now more aware of it because of Apple's popularity.

He may well be an "arrogant narcissist" (never met the man, but he also created products and ideas which have greatly helped the medical community & disabled people. His products have saved lives.

The whole idea of "the cloud" when it comes to computing is ridiculous! Why would anyone with any sense store their most important and personal information on servers that are controlled by "someone, somewhere?" As much as I love my Apple products, I think this was the worst idea ever dreamed up by that arrogant narcissist Steve Jobs. I realize that the horses are all out of the corral at this point but I myself will never use Dropbox, never join Facebook, and never ever rely on "the cloud." I will continue to back up my data automatically each morning on my LaCie external hard drive and I will never exhibit this lemming-like behavior even as I watch so many millions of others jump off the nearest cliff, "just because every one else is doing it." Wake up people! There is a reason all of these internet companies want you to "share" everything and it is not in your best interests.

I realize you probably haven't read the account the woman wrote, but she makes it clear she went to see a different comedian performing later in the night and was unfamiliar with Tosh. But for some reason, its more convenient for you to assume that she was just out to ruin everyone else's fun and screw up Tosh's act. For some reason, it doesn't occur to you that she might be a perfectly thick-skinned person who just happens to be sick and tired of men making rape jokes. And for some reason, you can't identify with how terrifying it must feel to be on the receiving end of the threat Tosh made after her outburst.

I'll leave it to you and everyone else here to guess what that reason might be.

Sorry, but attending a live comedy show with the purpose of looking for material you find offensive to your sensitivities is just plain dumm. Like walking up into an open flame and complaining you got burned.

I am sure that the person would have complained about some other joke, even if the subject of rape had never been brought up.

Just go see something else, something not offensive to your delicate skin.

Comedians try something new, and sometimes they mess up, after all, it is live, they do not have to chance to have 3 takes, then edit the best one. So he made a bad joke. It was a bad joke. I never heard the comedian advocate rape at all. Just a comedian who flubbed a joke. It happens. Boo him for it, and listen to the next joke, it might just be funny.

Humor usually isn't funny when it comes out of nowhere.  When a comedian goes on stage for the first time, it usually takes several minutes (at least) before people start thinking, "Hey, this guy is really funny."  But once a comedian has built up a cache of funny, then anything he or she says takes on that aura.  Don Rickles can walk out on stage and say "You're ugly!" and people will die laughing, on the spot, because they already know Don Rickles is funny.  Jack Benny could walk out and say nothing at all and people would still die laughing.  But what worked for Benny wouldn't work for Rickles, because they each built up very specific personalities.  Tosh is carving out a difficult space in the comic world -- he doesn't do the easy safe stuff.  Ultimately it might not come together for him, but the world would be a poorer place without his kind of experimentation.
"No exits" perhaps Martin, ha, ha.
Write, thoughtfully, once.
@rjon: It was Vonnegut, but yeah...........

Freedom ignited an eternal flame. Sartre's "existence precedes essence" describes the essential functionality of human beings to define themselves. It is the release of all bonds of church and state, of society and morality. Freedom is the basic innate condition of humanity. Aha! But what is humanity? If we are "made in the image of God", our actions define God as well as humanity. The ultimate K.I.S.S. principle is doing good, expressing compassion, without regard to the recipient. But we are so benumbed by the sheer profusion of the senses we fail to hear the crickets, the constants of mortal existence, and wonder "What's it all about, Alfie?" It turns out that happiness is inseparable from virtue. We can only define ourselves in actions. Our ancient history defines us in more enduring ways as social entities whose behavior is circumscribed by our interaction with society. Optimum existential function exits in an holistic gestalt which is more than the sum of its parts.

Thank you all for your careful consideration of my post! This is why I love crossword puzzle people. They are careful thinkers. Bottom line -- I don't think the "clever column name" adds enough to warrant the problem -- the inexcusable problem, I have to say -- of possibly, even possibly, giving away a theme. Wordplay is one of the most intelligent, fun features I turn to every day -- EVEN when the title isn't a clever hint at the answer.
And PS -- on my PC, with Windows 7, the name of the Wordplay column is right below the "Today's Puzzle" box. It's just too hard to ignore.
Apology accepted, Laszlo. Glad we got that sorted.

Unfortunately the rest of us didn't get to discover the trick for ourselves because when we went to print it out, your cute title -- "the only way IN" -- gave a huge hint at the answer. Just like yesterday's "Union Gig."  Please stop doing that! For a long time the title of this column was just one of the clues. Can't we go back to that? Or have your web guy stop printing your here's-the-answer-on-a-silver-platter title right next to the place where we have to go to print the puzzle out? Love sharing the puzzle with you. Hate having to figure out how to ignore you 'til I get there.

Don't ask me how she got into office to represent us.  There is a large backlash by MN right now over comments the governor made and I feel that a similar one is coming for her once that is dealt with.  I hope everyone reads this and understands that I cant even say a fraction of Minnesotans believe this, because they don't.  Only she does

Our state is progressive in densely populated areas like the Twin Cities. In the exurban and rural areas MN is very conservative. Mrs. Bachmann represents an area that covers both exurban and rural areas. We are one of the most segregated states politically and racially. Being a progressive when I hear Mrs. Bachmann in the news, I think to myself, "oh god what is crazy auntie Michelle up to now?"

Strangely she is beginning to grow on me because no MN representative has raised the bar on the absurd like Mrs. Bachmann and continued to get reelected. Yes, she may be a nut, but she's our nut.
Joe McCarthy lives on in Minnesota............will that progressive state repudiate this kind of "un-american activity" as Wisconsin once failed to do?

Where are the citizens of Minnesota? Is there no one in Ms. Bachmann's district that is willing to stand up to this woman and say "Have you no shame?"

I want to hear from her constituency. Why did you vote for her in 2010 and why will you return her to office in November?

Most likely the role would have gone to an East Asian actor, but this would have kept the film from being released in China, the world's second largest cinema market. (at the very least it would have been heavily censored)

Picking Kingsley and altering the character's origin was done to assuage the Chinese government. It would have been far more controversial if Chinese actor was cast in a role evocative of the "yellow peril" stereotype.

By going w/ Kingsley the studio is trying to avoid the race issue. Most likely, the writers have a clever reason as to why he will be called "The Mandarin." (just like in the comics)

I became truly aware of "yellow face" recently after watching Breakfast at Tiffany's with Mickey Rooney's shameful display. The director said that looking back, he regretted the choice of actor.
Why can't they find an Asian actor to play the part? No matter how good Kingsley is, the movie is tainted.
"Everybody else is paying strict attention."   Really?  That's not what I am hearing or seeing in popular, public dialogue and/or actions.
By 'everyone else' I mean all other living things beside most humans.

I have to laugh when that happens. A typo reduces a sentence to gibberish. Puts me in my place.
"Optimum existential function exists", not exits. We are just a cog in the wheel of life. But we need to perceive the big picture. The bison and the passenger pigeon were elemental in the landscape and the biosphere, part and parcel. It is a flow of energy, of nutrients and we are part of it. We have access to the intuitive blessing of consciousness only to the degree we use it. Everybody else is paying strict attention. They're passionately engaged. Only humans can survive being so self-absorbed as to require existentialism as a reflex.

I agree with Rance from Chicago. Serving in the military is certainly honorable, but that does not mean that not serving is dishonorable. There are many reasons for not serving, including physical disability that may still not be an obstacle to a career in public service.

Who is doing what to whom in Syria?

"The idea that a poorly organized, lightly armed opposition force could somehow get so close to the seat of power raised questions about the viability of a once unassailable police state."

As long as a dictator doesn't aspire to establish national sovereignty over the resources of his own country, or to chart an independent course at odds with American/Western hegemonic policy, all other crimes or "anti-democratic" acts are overlooked. If that line is perceived to be crossed, however, then the fat is in the fire. Such was the case with Saddam Hussein, Muammar Gaddafi and Omar Torrijos, and is true of Bashar al-Assad.

The latest deadly attack on the Syrian government points to high-level intelligence and coordination. The dramatic rise in military capability by the armed groups is a culmination of steadily increasing involvement of Western and Turkish Special Forces since conflict erupted on March 15, 2011, and the flow of weapons into Syria from Turkey funded by the Western-allied Persian Gulf Arab sheikhdoms.

The involvement of suicide bombers points to the Saudi and Qatari-backed Sunni extremists of Al Qaeda ilk, operating out of Libya, Iraq and Lebanon. These groups have a long, murky history of liaison with Western intelligence agencies going back to Soviet-era Afghanistan and more recently in the NATO toppling of Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi.

My brother-in-law is a farmer, lives in a rural area, and is a retired high school agriculture teacher. He also is a school board member for their county. Like many rural, agricultural areas, it has a high poverty rate. Even with his ag background, he still strongly advocates for the end of the long summer breaks as a way for his poor school district to not lose so much ground compared to richer districts.

A lot of work the kids do can be done before and after school anyway, especially in summer with long hours of daylight. When there is extreme heat midday, the full-time farmers often lay low and save work for the evening.
When a suicide bomber kills government officials in countries we like, we call it terrorism.

Every dog has his day.
Antonio Montana

Neil,
tell me you know that this was a US drone strike.

I agree with Rance Spergl.  I wish that every mother's son had found a way to avoid serving in America's wars when the draft was in effect.  And a hope now that every mother's son and daughter has a much better option for the future than volunteering to serve in the military.   There are far better ways to serve the nation.
Your post really offended me.  There is no way Sarah Palin could have run a post office. You belittle paper and buildings everywhere with your wild, irresponsible, boasts.

Hillary Clinton's motorcade was pelted with tomatoes and shoes during her recent Cairo trip by what was thought to be an anti-Muslim Brotherhood crowd incited to action by reporting from reliable news outlets such as Michelle Bachmann and Glen Beck. I thought their lunatic rants were just for home consumption and one had to drink the local water to be able to take their utterings seriously. Not so anymore.

McCain's denunciation of Bachmann's attack on Ms. Abedin should now be followed by a bipartisan vote to censure her.
Do we need to worry about Minnesota going for Romney?  After all, they elected Pawlenty and Bachmann to office.

I hope this discussion about a Romney VP will simply be relegated to political trivia after his defeat in November. But in any case, we need not worry too much about his eventual choice because the top of the ticket is enough to sink the ship anyway.

The bar was lowered for Romney four years ago when John McCain jeopardized the security and welfare of this nation when he chose a person who was barely qualified to run a post office let alone this country. So Romney need not sweat too much if all he's trying to do is improve on McCain's fateful mistake in 2008.

One thing we do know for certain: Romney won't be selecting Michele Bachmann as his number two. As if we needed another example of her hateful lunacy, Bachmann was one of five members of congress who recklessly tried to smear and destroy Huma Abedin, aide to Secretary Clinton, by unjustifiably suggesting she might have links to the Muslim Brotherhood and therefore could be a threat to this nation. Rep Bachmann is an utter disgrace to the political process. Her McCarthy-like tactics should be universally condemned by both parties, and by those from all across the political spectrum.

When a party is home to such reckless demagogues like Bachmann -- a woman who hypocritically wears her religion on her sleeve while at the same time showing little conscience in her attempt to ruin a life -- the selection pool for Romney for a qualified candidate that can enhance (or save) the ticket must not be that great.

Many competitive solvers who are regulars at the Amerian Crossword Puzzle Tournament practice online nightly and those are real times for them.

Hi MR,

First, welcome to Wordplay! Hope to see more of your comments.

Next, let me assure you that some of those scores are not legit. I am not sure how they do it, and I hope this won't shock you, but there are some people who cheat out there.

Having said that, some of my best friends are speed solvers, and I am always knocked out watching them blaze through a puzzle. Remember, for people like us -- and I count myself as someone who solves for enjoyment, not speed -- it's the journey, not the destination.

Hi all,

This is my first post after solving and periodically lurking on the blog comments for several years. Something has finally eaten at me enough to post this question.

According to the Top Finishers chart that ranks the fastest finishers, it seems that some are able to solve these puzzles in impossibly fast times. I was able to finish this Thursday puzzle but it took me thirty minutes. I understand that I am not fast and that isn't what bothers me. Yet, simply reading through the clues would take me at least a minute or two. How is it humanly possible to read the clues, figure them out, and type in the answers in just over three minutes?

I've seen the film Wordplay and know others are ridiculously fast, but wouldn't a person who could finish this puzzle in such a speedy time be a lock to win the competition every time? Are the times that logged on Top Finishers chart legit?

MR

i agree with another poster that all recent wars have been wars of empire cloaked in national security or other charades (remember "this is not about oil - it's about human rights?") So maybe not serving isn't by itself a horrible thing. But, the real question comes when folks like Cheney, Clinton, Bush and either Romney or, yes, Obama cavalierly send our youth (primarily our poor youth) off to fight and die for causes they would not have personally been willing to die for.

When I was in a private high school in 1968, Ted Kennedy came to address our students, and chose to tell us why a volunteer army was immoral - it leaves all the burden of war on the poorest among us, and lets the richest and most powerful among us wage war without paying the cost. We didn't want to hear that at the time, but he was right.

If we still had a draft, there would have been no Iraq/Afghanistan war, and that would have been a good thing. A veteran like Eisenhower who understood the price of war would make a very good candidate. Unfortunately, the last war hero that ran (John Kerry) mysteriously lost the ability to use his experience in any positive way whatsoever, and instead allowed the puffing, draft-dodging Bush to paint him as unpatriotic and a coward. Go figure. I think it shows how amazingly removed the majority of Americans (or at least the Americans who make the decisions) are from the realities of war.

Welcome to 21st century India - Anil! Why don't you enlighten Prithvi, who believes Jodhpur is about to roll in sex, drugs and rock-n-roll due to the influx of students! The illusions that Indians have about their country! It would be comic, if it were not tragic! The smugness of the Indian elite about their country is one reason why real change cannot happen here and highly patriarchal, regressive values will continue to persist well into the 21st  or 22nd century!

Thanks to NYT India Ink blog for highlighting this unique newspaper. It was a pleasure to read this paper online and discover that I can still read and understand this language. Choosing Sanskrit as a second language in high school is a common practice in Karnataka as it is considered "easy to score" than Kannada or Hindi as languages. We could get away writing substantial parts of the exam in English (analysis of Sanskrit pragraphs, literature and poetry).
So what?

Don't dismiss Prithvi's comments above.  India's higher education really should find a BALANCE that includes independence and high respect for Indian culture.  I don't know about Jodhpur.  Having said that, I can tell you that in Southern India, many universities and colleges in big cities and small towns have a very tough time with their students who are learning from Indian movies, TV shows, and Cell Phone downloads than learning skills that will put food on their plate.  Spend some time in any of the colleges or talk to educators, you will see it for yourself.
